document.title: An observation on the existence of stable generalized complex structures on ruled surfaces

document.abstract: We point out that any stable generalized complex structure on a sphere bundle over a closed surface of genus at least two must be of constant type.

authors.name: Rafael Torres

Paragraph.text: The canonical line bundle K(ùìò) ‚äÇ ‚àß‚Ä¢T*‚Çê(M) of a stable generalized complex structure ùìò on a smooth n-manifold M is generated pointwise by the complex differential form $$\rho = e^B + i\omega\wedge\Omega,$$ where B and \omega are real two forms and the complex form on the right side of (1.1) decomposes into $$\Omega = \theta_1 \wedge \cdots \wedge \theta_k$$ for (\theta_1, ‚Ä¶, \theta_k) a basis for L ‚à© T*‚Çê, and L is the +i-eigenbundle of ùìò (see [9, 10] and Cavalcanti‚ÄìGualtieri [4] for background and further details). A fundamental invariant of a stable generalized complex structure (M, ùìò) is its type, defined by Type(ùìò) = deg(\Omega) = k, as in [10, Section 3.1]. In dimension 4, the possible constant types are k ‚àà {0, 1, 2}. The value k = 0 corresponds to a stable generalized complex structure induced by a symplectic structure, while k = 2 corresponds to one induced by a complex structure. Stable generalized complex structures of type k = 1 have been studied by Bailey‚ÄìCavalcanti‚ÄìGualtieri [1] and Chen‚ÄìNie [6].

Moreover, there is now a myriad of examples of stable generalized complex structures in dimension 4 whose type jumps from k = 0 to k = 2 [2, 3, 5, 8, 10, 16, 17]. As Cavalcanti‚ÄìGualtieri have shown, for these kinds of stable generalized complex structures, the underlying smooth four-manifold need not support a symplectic nor a complex structure [2, 3]. The type change occurs along a smoothly embedded torus T ‚äÇ M, which is a path-connected component of the type change locus of ùìò. All known examples of such stable generalized complex structures in the literature share the common trait that the underlying closed four-manifold has nonnegative Euler characteristic. This raises the following question.
**Question 1.** Does there exist a closed four-manifold of negative Euler characteristic that admits a stable generalized complex structure with nonempty type change locus?

The main result of this short note puts Question 1 into perspective by exhibiting four-manifolds of negative Euler characteristic that solely admit stable generalized complex structures of constant type, a behavior that was not previously known to occur; cf. Remark 7.

Theorem.label: thm:A
Theorem.claim: **Theorem A.** The type change locus of a stable generalized complex structure on a sphere bundle over a closed surface of genus strictly greater than one is empty. In particular, any stable generalized complex structure on such a four-manifold arises from a K√§hler structure.

Paragraph.text: This note aims to make well-known classification theorems and results addressing the minimal genus function of a symplectic four-manifold (see [7, Chapter 2]) more widespread within the generalized complex geometry community. The main ingredient in the proof of Theorem A is Li‚ÄìLi‚Äôs solution to the minimal genus problem of smooth embeddings in sphere bundles over surfaces in [12] (see Theorems 4 and 5). The other ingredients in the proof are a pair of generalized complex cut-and-paste constructions of Cavalcanti‚ÄìGualtieri [2, 3], the symplectic Thom conjecture due to Oszv√°th‚ÄìSzab√≥ [15, Theorem 1.1], and Liu‚Äôs classification of irrational ruled symplectic four-manifolds [14] (see Theorem 3).
Key background results that are used in the proof of Theorem A are collected in this section with the purpose of making the short note as self-contained as possible.

Section.label: sec:cg-surgery
Section.header: 2.1 A relation between the symplectic Kodaira dimension and a stable generalized complex surgery

Paragraph.text: Cavalcanti‚ÄìGualtieri introduced in [2, Section 3] and [3, Section 4] a four-dimensional cut-and-paste operation that has been a fruitful source of examples of stable generalized complex four-manifolds; cf. Goto-Hayano [8]. Their main results can be rephrased as follows.

Theorem.label: thm:1
Theorem.claim: **Theorem 1 (Cavalcanti‚ÄìGualtieri [2, 3]).** Let $$(\widehat{M}, \mathcal{I})$$ be a stable generalized complex four-manifold whose type change locus has path-connected components $$\{\widehat{T}_1,\dots,\widehat{T}_n\}$$ for some $$n\in \mathbb{N}.$$ Suppose that each of these tori has self-intersection zero. There is a symplectic four-manifold $$(M,\omega)$$ with Euler characteristic and signature given by $$\chi(\widehat{M}) = \chi(M)\text{ and }\sigma(\widehat{M}) = \sigma(M),$$ as well as symplectically embedded tori $$T_1,\dots,T_n\subset (M,\omega)$$ of self-intersection zero.

Paragraph.text: The second Stiefel‚ÄìWhitney class of the four-manifolds of Theorem 1 need not coincide. Indeed, the setting of the example considered by Cavalcanti‚ÄìGualtieri [2, Example 4.2] is $$\widehat{M} = 3\mathbb{CP}^2 \# 19\overline{\mathbb{CP}}^2$$ and $$M$$ is a K3 surface.

Before discussing a relation between the symplectic Kodaira dimension of M and the characteristic numbers of $$\widehat{M},$$ recall the definition of the symplectic Kodaira dimension. Let $$(M,\omega)$$ be a minimal symplectic four-manifold and let $$K_\omega$$ be its canonical class (the first Chern class of any almost-complex structure on M compatible with \omega).

Definition.label: def:2
Definition.definition:
**Definition 2. The symplectic Kodaira dimension (Li [13, Definition 2.2]).** The symplectic Kodaira dimension $$\mathrm{Kod}(M,\omega)$$ of a minimal symplectic four-manifold $$(M,\omega)$$ is defined by:

‚Ä¢ $$\mathrm{Kod}(M,\omega) = -\infty$$ if $$K_\omega \cdot [\omega] < 0$$ or $$K_\omega \cdot K_\omega < 0.$$
‚Ä¢ $$\mathrm{Kod}(M,\omega) = 0$$ if $$K_\omega \cdot [\omega] = 0$$ and $$K_\omega \cdot K_\omega = 0.$$
‚Ä¢ $$\mathrm{Kod}(M,\omega) = 1$$ if $$K_\omega \cdot [\omega] > 0$$ and $$K_\omega \cdot K_\omega = 0.$$
‚Ä¢ $$\mathrm{Kod}(M,\omega) = 2$$ if $$K_\omega \cdot [\omega] > 0$$ and $$K_\omega \cdot K_\omega > 0.$$

The symplectic Kodaira dimension of a nonminimal symplectic four-manifold is defined as that of any of its minimal models.

Paragraph.text: A minimal symplectic four-manifold (M, \omega) with \(\pi_1(M)\) of exponential growth has $$\mathrm{Kod}(M,\omega) = -\infty$$ if and only if M is irrationally ruled by a result of Liu [14]. All such four-manifolds admit a K√§hler structure and are diffeomorphic to either the product $$S^2 \times \Sigma_g$$ or the nontrivial bundle $$S^2\widetilde\times \Sigma_g$$ in the absence of smoothly embedded spheres of self-intersection ‚àí1 (see [13, Section 3] for a guide to the literature). We state Liu‚Äôs classification as follows.

Theorem.label: thm:3
Theorem.claim: **Theorem 3 (Liu [14]).** Let $$(M,\omega)$$ be a symplectic four-manifold with $$\mathrm{Kod}(M,\omega) = -\infty$$ and whose fundamental group has exponential growth. Then M is diffeomorphic to $$M_g \#\,k\,\mathbb{CP}^2$$ where $$M_g$$ is a sphere bundle over a surface of genus at least two and $$k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\ge 0}.$$

Paragraph.text: The Euler characteristic of a minimal symplectic four-manifold $$(M,\omega)$$ with $$\mathrm{Kod}(M,\omega) = -\infty$$ is negative if and only if its fundamental group has exponential growth. The precise diffeomorphism type of the four-manifold of Theorem 3 is determined from its intersection form over \(\mathbb{Z}\) [7, Definition 1.2.1] and/or its Euler characteristic, signature, and second Stiefel‚ÄìWhitney class.

Section.label: sec:min-genus
Section.header: 2.2 The minimal genus of symplectic surfaces in irrational ruled symplectic four-manifolds

Paragraph.text: The main ingredient in the proof of Theorem A is work of B.-H. Li and T.-J. Li [12, Theorems 1 and 2] that solves the minimal genus problem for smooth embeddings of surfaces in irrational ruled symplectic four-manifolds. We recall their statements below.

Theorem.label: thm:4
Theorem.claim:
**Theorem 4 (Li-Li [12, Theorem 1]).** Let a and b be nonnegative integers, and consider the second homology classes
\( x = [\{pt\} \times \Sigma_g] \quad \text{and} \quad y = [S^2 \times \{pt\}]. \)
The minimal genus \(g_\xi\) of \(\xi = a x + b y \in H_2(S^2 \times \Sigma_g)\) is given by:
\[
   g_\xi = \begin{cases}
       (a - 1)(g - 1 + b) + g & \text{if } a \neq 0,\\
       0 & \text{otherwise.}\end{cases}
\]

Theorem.label: thm:5
Theorem.claim:
**Theorem 5 (Li-Li [12, Theorem 2]).** Let \(S^2\widetilde\times \Sigma_g\) be the nontrivial sphere bundle over a surface of genus \(g > 0\). Let x be the homology class of its section and y the homology class of a fiber. The minimal genus \(g_\xi\) of \(\xi = a x + b y \in H_2(S^2\widetilde\times \Sigma_g)\) is given by:
\[
  g_\xi = \begin{cases}
     (a' - 1)\bigl( (g - 1) + \tfrac12 |a' + 2 b'| \bigr) + g & \text{if } a \neq 0,\\
     0 & \text{otherwise,}\end{cases}
\]
where \(a' = |a|\) and \(b' = \tfrac{a}{|a|} b\) when \(a \neq 0\).

Paragraph.text: From these theorems, we obtain the following corollary, pointed out by the referee.

Theorem.label: cor:6
Theorem.claim: **Corollary 6.** Let M be a sphere bundle over a surface of genus strictly greater than one. If a homology class \(\xi \in H_2(M)\) is represented by a torus T, then \(\xi\) is a multiple of the homology class of the fiber of M. In particular, \(\xi^2 = 0\) and T is not a minimum genus representative of \(\xi\).

Paragraph.text: There are stable generalized complex structures of constant type \(k\in\{0,2\}\) on both bundles \(S^2\times\Sigma_g\) and \(S^2\widetilde\times\Sigma_g\) that come from their structure as irrational ruled complex surfaces. They can also be equipped with stable generalized complex structures of constant type \(k=1\) by considering the sphere as the complex projective line and the volume form on the closed surface of genus g.

To see that neither of these four-manifolds admits a stable generalized complex structure with at least one connected component in its type change locus, we argue by contradiction. Let \(\widehat{M}\) be a sphere bundle over a closed surface of genus at least two and suppose there is a stable generalized complex structure \((\widehat{M},\mathcal{I})\) whose type change locus has at least one connected component. Two scenarios must be considered:

1. There is at least one path-connected component \(\widehat{T}\subset\widehat{M}\) of the type change locus of \(\mathcal{I}\) with nonzero self-intersection.\
2. Every path-connected component \(\widehat{T}\) of the type change locus of \(\mathcal{I}\) has self-intersection zero.

The first scenario is immediately ruled out by Corollary 6. To rule out the second, we apply Theorem 1 to \((\widehat{M},\mathcal{I})\) and obtain a symplectic four-manifold \((M,\omega)\) with signature \(\sigma(M)=\sigma(\widehat{M})=0\) and Euler characteristic \(\chi(M)=\chi(\widehat{M})<0.\) These values imply that \((M,\omega)\) is a minimal symplectic four-manifold whose fundamental group has exponential growth. By Liu‚Äôs classification (Theorem 3), M is either \(S^2\times\Sigma_g\) or \(S^2\widetilde\times\Sigma_g\). Theorem 1 guarantees a symplectic torus \(T\subset M\) of self-intersection zero, and by the symplectic Thom conjecture of Oszv√°th‚ÄìSzab√≥ [15], that torus would be genus-minimizing. However, this contradicts Corollary 6. Thus, the second scenario is impossible, and the proof is complete.

Remark.label: rem:7
Remark.remark: It is well known that the number of path-connected components of the type change locus of a stable generalized complex structure on \(S^2\times S^2\) and \(S^2\times T^2\) can be chosen to be arbitrarily large [8, 16, 17].
